msDesc.head: Letter from Mary Russell Mitford to Sir William Elford, 1819 June 29.

support.p: Paper. Two sheets with six page surfaces photographed. Folded in thirds twice: one sheet of quarto-post containing pages 1, 2, 3, and 4, and one sheet of half quarto-post containing pages 5 and 6.

Address leaf bearing a sepia-inked stamp with a double circle topped by a crown, the center of which reads
FREE
2 JY 2
1819

condition.p: A round grease mark has been left by the seal on pages 1 and 5. The second sheet (pages 5 and 6) is torn on right edge of page 5 where wax seal was removed.

sealDesc.p: Red round wax seal with curved line, partially broken, adhered to page 6.

handNotes.handNote: Red crayon or thick red pencil. Probably a different hand from Mitford's that marks many of her letters, sometimes drawing diagonal lines across pages, and sometimes writing words overtop and perpendicularly across Mitford's writing. A red line is drawn from top left to bottom right of each of the first five pages. On the sixth page, a red line is drawn from top left to bottom right across each of the two text blocks. There is no red crayon across the address text block.

Someone, apparently other than Mitford, perhaps cataloging letters and describing them, who left grey pencil marks and numbered her letters now in the Reading Central Library's collection. This letter is numbered "12" in the top left of the first leaf.

editorialDecl.p: Mitford’s spelling and punctuation are retained, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in the manuscript. Where Mitford’s spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements “choice," “sic," and “reg" to encode both Mitford’s spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

div.p:
We do indeed very sincerely sympathise, My dear Sir William in the shock you must have felt at the death of Mr. Champernowne Till your letter arrived we were ignorant of this melancholy event-- How much you must have felt it after your recent companionship! Even I--though never having the pleasure of seeing him--had yet a feeling of acquaintance with Mr. Champernowne. We had expected him, talked of him, thought of him--he had the goodness to come this way that we might enjoy the pleasure of your company. Oh there are many men whom I know in all the ceremony of bowing & curtsying that I should not have regretted half so much. I will talk no more on this distressing subject--but turn to the latter part of your letter your admirable critique & analysis of Camilla. First of all I must beg leave to observe that I must have written even worse than ordinary if I could by any means convey to you the idea of disapproving the practice of reading to find fault. I rather think that I told you I was sometimes addicted to this practice myself. A piece of candour which however mentions it may appear was at least not very necessary to a person of your sagacity--inasmuch as full one half of the many reams of paper which you have had the trouble of reading or not reading signed M. R. M. have been taken up with certain impertinent remarks which if not finding fault are very much like it--and ad to your one specimen of faultfinding it has given me so much pleasure that I very sincerely wish you may take to the custom. I never read so good a Review of a novel--or so fair a one--you give your reasons--which reviewers by profession never do--& have
quite fortified me in my old opinions by telling me why I thought so. The only point I cannot quiteentirely give up is Sir Hugh--He would be, as you say, utterly incapable of conducting the affairs of life--he commits great injustice from want of knowing better & from the mistake into which wiser people than Sir Hugh are apt to fall the wish of buying love,--but he has to me qualities that redeem all his faults of understanding--a softness of heart, a glow of good humour, an overflow of kindness, an entire absence of selfishness--a real & delightful simplicity that makes me love him--even against my conviction. Mr. Dubster I abandon. Though he has an occasional mixture of oddity & his self-pity resulting from his intense selfishness is extremely diverting--rarely I admit but still very diverting--don't you remember the "nobody never gives me nothing"--which is as good as any parallel passage in

person.note: Champernowne of Dartington Hall, Devon, was born Arthur Harington, and took the name of his maternal grandfather on 7 May 1774 when he succeeded to his late mother's inheritance. He served very briefly in Parliament (8 Nov. 1806 - 19 Feb. 1807), representing Saltash. His parliamentary career ended six days after his first, and only known, parliamentary action, a vote with the minority against the Grenville ministry. Champernowne traveled regularly to the Continent and purchased several paintings by Italian and Flemish Old Masters. The bulk of his collection was auctioned in 1820, after his death. In Treasures of Art in Great Britain, Gustav Friedrich Waagen named Champernowne among the "most distinguished collectors in England sinc 1792, who, by transplanting the most admirable works of art into their country, have conferred upon it a lasting benefit" (London: John Murray, 1854; Vol. I, pp. 26-27). Sources: The History of Parliament Online; Oxford Art Online.
